example.translation: ‘What have you bought in town? – Peas and grains.’
‘What is it that is on the ground?’ – ‘It is grass.’
‘the wine, that has been water’

example.label: bkm:Ref93745057
example.source: In the street, I saw a cat and a dog. The dog was barking furiously. It is perhaps symptomatic that examples of the anaphoric use of definite noun phrases in the literature tend to contain antecedents which are parts of a conjoined noun phrase: at least in natural speech, pronouns tend to be preferred to full noun phrases as straightforward anaphors in most contexts, and we need a structure such as a conjoined NP for there to be two equally possible antecedents, in which case a definite NP is motivated.

example.label: bkm:Ref93745078
example.source: I met the author of Syntactic Structures.

example.label: bkm:Ref75942712
example.source: I have to fix my computer: there is some problem with the hard disk.
Last year, I saw a film by Ingmar Bergman. I would like to see that/the film again.
